case_name: M/s. Northbrook Jute Co., Ltd. and Dalhousie Jute Mills v. Their Workmen

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 141 of 1959 is an appeal by special leave from the Award dated July 19, 1958, of the Fourth Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal, in Case No. VIII-240 166 /57.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 141 of 1959. Appeal by special leave from the Award dated July 19, 1958, of the Fourth Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal, in Case No. VIII-240  166 /57.

facts.text: The judgment of the Court was delivered on March 23, 1960, by DAS GUPTA, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. March 23. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS GUPTA, J.-On December 13, 1957, the Government of West Bengal referred under s. 10 of the Industrial Disputes, Act the following dispute between M S. Northbrook Jute Co., Ltd., and Dalhousie Jute Mills Who are appellants before us and their workmen-

facts.text: Government of West Bengal referred a dispute under s. 10 of the Industrial Disputes Act on December 13, 1957, between Northbrook Jute Co., Ltd., Dalhousie Jute Mills (appellants) and their workmen.

anchor.surface_text: On December 13, 1957, the Government of West Bengal referred under s. 10 of the Industrial Disputes, Act the following dispute between M S. Northbrook Jute Co., Ltd., and Dalhousie Jute Mills Who are appellants before us and their workmen- Do the proposals of rationalisation in the above two mills involve any increase in workload ?

facts.text: The referred dispute was: Do the proposals of rationalisation in the two mills involve any increase in workload? If so, what relief are the workmen entitled to?

anchor.surface_text: Do the proposals of rationalisation in the above two mills involve any increase in workload ? If so, what relief the workmen are entitled to ? Almost a month before this the proposal of introducing a rationalisation scheme in time mills of these companypanies had been companysidered at an extraordinary meeting of the Works Committee and the Committee had agreed to the proposal.

facts.text: Almost a month before December 13, 1957, the proposal of introducing a rationalisation scheme in the two mills was considered at an extraordinary meeting of the Works Committee and the Committee agreed to the proposal.

anchor.surface_text: Almost a month before this the proposal of introducing a rationalisation scheme in time mills of these companypanies had been companysidered at an extraordinary meeting of the Works Committee and the Committee had agreed to the proposal. facts.text: Notice under s. 9A of the Industrial Disputes Act was given by the companies to the Unions of their workmen.

anchor.surface_text: A numberice tinder s. 9A of the Industrial Disputes Act was then given by the companypanies to the Unions of their workmen and it was because the workmen objected to the introduction of the rationalisation scheme that the dispute arose and was refer- red by the Government to the Tribunal.

facts.text: Workmen objected to the introduction of the rationalisation scheme, leading to the dispute being referred to the Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: and it was because the workmen objected to the introduction of the rationalisation scheme that the dispute arose and was refer- red by the Government to the Tribunal. On December 16 when the above reference was pending before the Tribunal the management. of these mills put the rationalisation scheme into operation but the workmen refused to do the additional work placed on them by the scheme.

facts.text: On December 16, 1957, while the reference was pending before the Tribunal, the management of the mills put the rationalisation scheme into operation.

anchor.surface_text: On December 16 when the above reference was pending before the Tribunal the management. of these mills put the rationalisation scheme into operation but the workmen refused to do the additional work placed on them by the scheme. Later the same day the mills declared a lock-out.

facts.text: On December 16, 1957, the workmen refused to do the additional work placed on them by the rationalisation scheme.

anchor.surface_text: the management. of these mills put the rationalisation scheme into operation but the workmen refused to do the additional work placed on them by the scheme. Later the same day the mills declared a lock-out. Work was however resumed again in all departments excepting the weaving and finishing departments on December 20,

facts.text: On December 16, 1957, later the same day, the mills declared a lock-out.

anchor.surface_text: Later the same day the mills declared a lock-out. Work was however resumed again in all departments excepting the weaving and finishing departments on December 20, and in these two departments on December 21, as a result of a settlement arrived at between the workmen represented by their Unions and the Mills as regards the introduction of the rationalisation scheme.

facts.text: Work resumed in all departments except weaving and finishing on December 20, 1957, and in weaving and finishing on December 21, 1957, as a result of a settlement between workmen Unions and Mills regarding rationalisation scheme.

anchor.surface_text: Work was however resumed again in all departments excepting the weaving and finishing departments on December 20, and in these two departments on December 21, as a result of a settlement arrived at between the workmen represented by their Unions and the Mills as regards the introduction of the rationalisation scheme. But a dispute arose as regards the payment of wages to workmen for their dues during the period when the mills were closed, viz.,

facts.text: A dispute arose regarding payment of wages to workmen for the period the mills were closed: December 16 to 20 in weaving and finishing departments, and December 16 to 19 in other departments.

anchor.surface_text: But a dispute arose as regards the payment of wages to workmen for their dues during the period when the mills were closed, viz., 16th December to 20th December in the weaving and finishing departments and 16th December to 19th December in all other departments. This dispute was also referred to the Tribunal by an order of the Government dated February 1, 1958.

facts.text: The wage dispute was referred to the Tribunal by Government order dated February 1, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: This dispute was also referred to the Tribunal by an order of the Government dated February 1, 1958. The earlier issue as regards the proposed introduction of the rationalisation scheme was also amended in view of what had happened in the meantime by substituting therefore -- Have the rationalisation effected in the above two mills since 16th December, 1957,

facts.text: The earlier issue was amended to: Have the rationalisation effected since December 16, 1957, involved any increase in workload? To what relief are workers entitled?

anchor.surface_text: The earlier issue as regards the proposed introduction of the rationalisation scheme was also amended in view of what had happened in the meantime by substituting therefore -- Have the rationalisation effected in the above two mills since 16th December, 1957, involved any increase in the workload ? To what relief the workers are entitled to ?

facts.text: The Tribunal's decision on the rationalisation issue was against the workmen and is no longer disputed.

anchor.surface_text: We are numberlonger companycerned with this issue as the decision of the Tribunal thereon which is against the workmen is numberlonger disputed. As regards the other two disputes the Tribunal has made an award in favour of the workmen that they are entitled to wages for the period of absence above-mentioned.

facts.text: Tribunal awarded workmen entitled to wages for the period of absence due to closure.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the other two disputes the Tribunal has made an award in favour of the workmen that they are entitled to wages for the period of absence above-mentioned. On this question the workmens case before the Tribunal was that the reason that workmen companyld numberdo any work on the days in question was the illegal look-out by the employers the employers case was that the workmen had struck work illegally,

facts.text: Workmen's case before Tribunal: workmen could not do work due to illegal lock-out by employers.

anchor.surface_text: On this question the workmens case before the Tribunal was that the reason that workmen companyld numberdo any work on the days in question was the illegal look-out by the employers the employers case was that the workmen had struck work illegally, and so the closure of the mills on the 16th of December after such strike was number illegal or unjustified.

facts.text: Employers' case: workmen struck work illegally on December 16, 1957, so closure was not illegal.

anchor.surface_text: the employers case was that the workmen had struck work illegally, and so the closure of the mills on the 16th of December after such strike was number illegal or unjustified. The Tribunal was of opinion that the eimloyers attempt to put the rationalisation scheme into effect on the 16th December was a companytravention of s. 33 of the Industrial Disputes Act,

facts.text: Tribunal held that employers' implementation of rationalisation scheme on December 16, 1957, contravened s. 33; workmen's refusal not illegal strike; employers' closure illegal lock-out.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal was of opinion that the eimloyers attempt to put the rationalisation scheme into effect on the 16th December was a companytravention of s. 33 of the Industrial Disputes Act, and so, the workmens refusal to works in accordance with that scheme was number an illegal strike and the employers closure of the mills was illegal.

facts.text: Workmens representatives on Works Committee agreed to introduction of scheme, as per resolution.

anchor.surface_text: That the workmens representatives on the Works Committee agreed to the introduction of the scheme by the companypanies whenever they desired is established by a companyy of the resolution of the Works Committee.

facts.text: Notice under s. 9A was given before December 13, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The next argument was that whatever alteration was effected in the companyditions of service, was made, on the date when numberice under s. 9A was given and that being before the 13th December there was numbercontravention of s. 33.

facts.text: Rationalisation scheme involved allocating machines so fewer workmen needed, surplus discharged, more work for same wages.

anchor.surface_text: The whole basis of the scheme was so to allocate the machines to workmen, as to enable fewer workmen to work the machines than the number previously required so that surplus workmen companyld be discharged. The object was to decrease the companyt of production. The method adopted for attaining the object was to obtain more work from the workmen for approximately the same wages.

facts.text: Mr. Fraser, company's witness, stated previously two hands per machine in batching department, now two hands for two machines.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Fraser, the companypanys witness, stated in his evidence that while previously for every machine in the batching department, there were two hands, number there are two hands for two machines.

facts.text: Companies had surplus labour, were losing heavily; decision to rationalise taken in November previous year.

anchor.surface_text: In giving the reasons for the introduction of the scheme, he said we had surplus labour in both the mills. The companypany was losing heavily. Till then we depended on natural wastage and did number think of rationalisation in November last year, the decision was taken to take action on rationalisation.

facts.text: Court concluded Tribunal was right: closure was illegal lock-out, workmen entitled to wages for absence period.

anchor.surface_text: Our companyclusion therefore is that the Tribunal was right in its opinion that the closure of the mills by the employer amounted to an illegal lock-out, and the workmen, unable to work in companysequence of the lockout, are entitled to wages for the period of absence, used by such lock-out.

issues.text: Whether the workmen are entitled to wages for the period of absence during the mill closure from December 16, 1957?

anchor.surface_text: This dispute was also referred to the Tribunal by an order of the Government dated February 1, 1958. The earlier issue as regards the proposed introduction of the rationalisation scheme was also amended in view of what had happened in the meantime by substituting therefore -- Have the rationalisation effected in the above two mills since 16th December, 1957, involved any increase in the workload ? To what relief the workers are entitled to ? We are numberlonger companycerned with this issue as the decision of the Tribunal thereon which is against the workmen is numberlonger disputed. As regards the other two disputes the Tribunal has made an award in favour of the workmen that they are entitled to wages for the period of absence above-mentioned.

issues.text: Whether putting the rationalisation scheme into effect on December 16, 1957 contravened section 33 of the Industrial Disputes Act?

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal was of opinion that the eimloyers attempt to put the rationalisation scheme into effect on the 16th December was a companytravention of s. 33 of the Industrial Disputes Act, and so, the workmens refusal to works in accordance with that scheme was number an illegal strike and the employers closure of the mills was illegal. Learned companynsel for the employer-mills has tried to companyvince us that they had acted in accordance with law, in introducing the rationalisation scheme on the 16th December.

anchor.surface_text: He pointed out that the Works Committee duly companystituted under the Act had companysidered the scheme and approved of it, and argued that as the workmens representatives on the Works Committee bad agreed to the scheme, the workmen themselves should be taken to have agreed to it. That the workmens representatives on the Works Committee agreed to the introduction of the scheme by the companypanies whenever they desired is established by a companyy of the resolution of the Works Committee. It has to be numbericed however that the workmens representatives on the Works Committee do number represent the workmen for all purposes, but only for the purpose of the functions of the Works Committee. anchor.surface_text: The next argument was that whatever alteration was effected in the companyditions of service, was made, on the date when numberice under s. 9A was given and that being before the 13th December there was numbercontravention of s. 33. There is in our opinion numbersubstance in this companytention, Section 9A in accordance with which the numberice was given provides that No employer who proposes to effect any change in the companyditions of service applicable to any workmen in respect of any matter specified in the Fourth Schedule, shall effect such change-  a  without giving to the workmen likely to be affected by such a numberice

issues.text: Whether the rationalisation scheme constituted an alteration in conditions of service to the prejudice of the workmen?

anchor.surface_text: It was further companytended that in any case, the alteration was number to the prejudice of the workmen. How such a companytention can be seriously made is difficult to understand. The whole basis of the scheme was so to allocate the machines to workmen, as to enable fewer workmen to work the machines than the number previously required so that surplus workmen companyld be discharged. The object was to decrease the companyt of production. The method adopted for attaining the object was to obtain more work from the workmen for approximately the same wages. However laudable the object be, it cannot be doubted for a moment that the scheme prejudiced the workmen seriously.

issues.text: Whether the workmen's refusal to work under the rationalisation scheme amounted to an illegal strike?

anchor.surface_text: Lastly it was companytended that even if the introduction of the rationalisation scheme was a companytravention of s. 33 the workmens remedy lay in applying under s. 33A, and that they were number entitled to strike work. Section 33A numberdoubt gives the workmen aggrieved by the companytravention by the employer of s. 33 to apply to the Tribunal for relief but the existence of this remedy does number mean that the workmen were bound to work under the altered companyditions of service, even though these were in clear companytravention of law.

arguments.claim: The closure of the mills by the employer amounted to an illegal lock-out, and the workmen, unable to work in consequence of the lockout, are entitled to wages for the period of absence caused by such lock-out.

anchor.surface_text: Our companyclusion therefore is that the Tribunal was right in its opinion that the closure of the mills by the employer amounted to an illegal lock-out, and the workmen, unable to work in companysequence of the lockout, are entitled to wages for the period of absence, used by such lock-out.

holdings.text: The fact that the workmens representatives on the Works Committee agreed to the introduction of the rationalisation scheme is therefore in no way binding on the workmen or their Union.

anchor.surface_text: The fact that the workmens representatives on the Works Committee agreed to the introduction of the rationalisation scheme is therefore in no way binding on the workmen or their Union.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Works Committee functions under s.3(2) limited to promoting amity, commenting on common concerns, composing differences; cannot decide substantial service changes or bind unions; follows Kemp & Co. precedent.

holdings.text: The conditions of service do not stand changed, either when the proposal is made or the notice is given but only when the change is actually effected.

anchor.surface_text: The conditions of service do not stand changed, either when the proposal is made or the notice is given but only when the change is actually effected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.9A provides three stages: proposal, notice, actual effect after 21 days; for s.33, alteration timing is when change implemented, here post-reference.

holdings.text: The introduction of the rationalisation scheme was therefore clearly an alteration of conditions of service to the prejudice of the workmen.

anchor.surface_text: The introduction of the rationalisation scheme was therefore clearly an alteration of conditions of service to the prejudice of the workmen.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme allocated more machines per worker, increased workload for same wages, discharged surplus labour, reducing production cost at workers' expense.

holdings.text: The Tribunal has therefore rightly held that this introduction was a contravention of s. 33.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal has therefore rightly held that this introduction was a contravention of s. 33.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prejudicial alteration in conditions (per Fourth Schedule) effected during pending tribunal proceedings, violating s.33 prohibition.

holdings.text: Section 33A no doubt gives the workmen aggrieved by the contravention by the employer of s. 33 to apply to the Tribunal for relief but the existence of this remedy does not mean that the workmen were bound to work under the altered conditions of service, even though these were in clear contravention of law. When they refused to do the additional work which the rationalisation scheme required them to do, they refused to do work, which the employer had no right in law to ask them to do. It is difficult to say that this amounted to a strike by the workmen but even if it could be said to be a strike such strike was certainly not illegal or unjustified.

anchor.surface_text: Section 33A no doubt gives the workmen aggrieved by the contravention by the employer of s. 33 to apply to the Tribunal for relief but the existence of this remedy does not mean that the workmen were bound to work under the altered conditions of service, even though these were in clear contravention of law. When they refused to do the additional work which the rationalisation scheme required

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.33A provides optional remedy for contravention; does not oblige workmen to accept or work under illegal prejudicial changes demanded in breach of s.33; such refusal neither strike nor illegal.

holdings.text: Our conclusion therefore is that the Tribunal was right in its opinion that the closure of the mills by the employer amounted to an illegal lock-out, and the workmen, unable to work in consequence of the lockout, are entitled to wages for the period of absence, caused by such lock-out.

anchor.surface_text: Our conclusion therefore is that the Tribunal was right in its opinion that the closure of the mills by the employer amounted to an illegal lock-out, and the workmen, unable to work in consequence of the lockout, are entitled to wages for the period of absence, caused by such lock-out.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.33 contravention by scheme implementation led to justified refusal (not illegal strike), making subsequent employer closure illegal lock-out; workmen entitled to wages during resultant absence.

anchor.surface_text: Kemp and Company Ltd. v. Their Workmen   that the Works Committees are numbermally companycerned with problems arising in the day to day working of the companycern and the functions of the Works Committee are to ascertain the grievances of the employees and when occasion arises to arrive at some agreement also. But the function and the responsibility of the works companymittee as their very numberenclature indicates cannot go beyond recommendation and as such they are more or less bodies who in the first instance endeavour to companypose the differences and the final decision rests with the union as a whole. The fact that the workmens representatives on the Works Committee agreed to the introduction of the  1  1955 1 L.L.J. 48.

precedents.case_name: Kemp and Company Ltd. v. Their Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: Works Committees are normally concerned with day to day working problems, ascertain grievances, arrive at agreements, but functions limited to recommendations, final decision rests with the union
precedents.cited_holding: the Works Committees are numbermally companycerned with problems arising in the day to day working of the companycern and the functions of the Works Committee are to ascertain the grievances of the employees and when occasion arises to arrive at some agreement also. But the function and the responsibility of the works companymittee as their very numberenclature indicates cannot go beyond recommendation and as such they are more or less bodies who in the first instance endeavour to companypose the differences and the final decision rests with the union as a whole.
